tables.Name: Chondroblastoma
tables.Presentation: Bone or joint pain in adolescent
tables.Radiograph Findings/Location: Epiphysis of long bones, may cross growth plate

tables.Name: Enchondroma
tables.Presentation: Soft tissue mass in hands or feet of adolescent; seen in Ollier Disease or Mafucci Syndrome
tables.Radiograph Findings/Location: Metaphysis of long bones in hands or feet; oval lesion with sclerotic edges and central lucency
tables.Clinical Importance: Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma if multiple lesions present

tables.Name: Langerhans cell histiocytosis of bone
tables.Presentation: Painful swelling of skull in children, typically frontal bone, or long bones
tables.Clinical Importance: Lesion of skull can be associated with diabetes insipidus or other CNS disease; pathological fracture of long bone

tables.Name: Osteoblastoma
tables.Presentation: Adolescent male with chronic pain in spine, most often seen in posterior column
tables.Radiograph Findings/Location: Similar to osteoid osteoma but typically > 2cm
tables.Clinical Importance: May appear like osteoid osteoma on plain film but DOES NOT respond to Aspirin/NSAIDs

tables.Name: Osteochondroma
tables.Presentation: Adolescent male with painless mass over distal femur
tables.Radiograph Findings/Location: Osseous spur that arises from cortex pointing away from joint
tables.Clinical Importance: Observation without treatment; small risk of transformation to chondrosarcoma

tables.Name: Osteoid Osteoma
tables.Presentation: Adolescent male with bone pain over femur; pain worse at night and unrelated to activity
tables.Radiograph Findings/Location: Radiolucent nidus with sclerotic edges most often seen in proximal femur
tables.Clinical Importance: Nidus produces prostaglandins, Aspirin/NSAIDs can relieve pain; most soft resolve

tables.Name: Adamantinoma
tables.Presentation: Bone pain over anterior tibia in adolescent or young adult
tables.Radiograph Findings: Soap bubble osteolytic appearance on plain radiograph
tables.Clinical Importance: Metastasis to lungs; may need amputation

tables.Name: Chordoma
tables.Presentation: Constant pain if in sacrum; neurological deficits if at base of skull, most commonly in cranial nerves to the eye
tables.Radiograph Findings: Plain radiograph will show a destructive bone lesion often with an associated soft tissue mass
tables.Clinical Importance: Slow growing but locally aggressive; metastasis is uncommon, local recurrence is much more likely

tables.Name: Fibrosarcoma and Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma
tables.Presentation: Similar to osteosarcoma except malignant fibroblasts but less common
tables.Radiograph Findings: Most common in distal femur and proximal tibia

tables.Name: Primary bone lymphoma
tables.Presentation: Adult > 40 years of age with bone pain or pathologic fracture
tables.Clinical Importance: 5 year survival is greater than 50% with radiation and chemotherapy
